trans-unit.source: Creating an Oracle Database virtual machine in Azure
trans-unit.target: Creating an Oracle Database virtual machine in Azure

trans-unit.source: Step through an example of creating an Oracle virtual machine in Microsoft Azure and then creating an Oracle Database on it.
trans-unit.target: Step through an example of creating an Oracle virtual machine in Microsoft Azure and then creating an Oracle Database on it.

trans-unit.source: Creating an Oracle Database virtual machine in Azure
trans-unit.target: Creating an Oracle Database virtual machine in Azure

trans-unit.source: The following example shows you how you can create a virtual machine (VM) based on a Microsoft-provided Oracle Database image running on Windows Server 2012 in Azure.
trans-unit.target: The following example shows you how you can create a virtual machine (VM) based on a Microsoft-provided Oracle Database image running on Windows Server 2012 in Azure.

trans-unit.source: There are two steps.
trans-unit.target: There are two steps.

trans-unit.source: First, create the VM, and then create the Oracle Database inside the VM.
trans-unit.target: First, create the VM, and then create the Oracle Database inside the VM.

trans-unit.source: The example shown is Oracle Database version 12c, but the steps are virtually identical for version 11g.
trans-unit.target: The example shown is Oracle Database version 12c, but the steps are virtually identical for version 11g.

trans-unit.source: To create an Oracle Database VM in Azure
trans-unit.target: To create an Oracle Database VM in Azure

trans-unit.source: Log in to the [Azure portal](https://ms.portal.azure.com/).
trans-unit.target: Log in to the [Azure portal](https://ms.portal.azure.com/).

trans-unit.source: Click **Marketplace**, click **Compute**, and then type **Oracle** into the search box.
trans-unit.target: Click **Marketplace**, click **Compute**, and then type **Oracle** into the search box.

trans-unit.source: Select one of the available Oracle Database images including **version 11g, version 12c, Standard Edition, Enterprise Edition, or one of the popular options or advanced options bundles.** Review the information about the image you select (such as minimum recommended size), and then click **Next**.
trans-unit.target: Select one of the available Oracle Database images including **version 11g, version 12c, Standard Edition, Enterprise Edition, or one of the popular options or advanced options bundles.** Review the information about the image you select (such as minimum recommended size), and then click **Next**.

trans-unit.source: Specify a **Host Name** for the VM.
trans-unit.target: Specify a **Host Name** for the VM.

trans-unit.source: Specify a **User Name** for the VM.
trans-unit.target: Specify a **User Name** for the VM.

trans-unit.source: Note that this user is for remotely logging in to the VM; this is not the Oracle database user name.
trans-unit.target: Note that this user is for remotely logging in to the VM; this is not the Oracle database user name.

trans-unit.source: Specify and confirm a password for the VM, or provide a SSH Public Key.
trans-unit.target: Specify and confirm a password for the VM, or provide a SSH Public Key.

trans-unit.source: Choose a **Pricing Tier**.
trans-unit.target: Choose a **Pricing Tier**.

trans-unit.source: Note that Recommended Pricing Tiers are displayed by default, to see all configuration options, click **View all** on the top right.
trans-unit.target: Note that Recommended Pricing Tiers are displayed by default, to see all configuration options, click **View all** on the top right.

trans-unit.source: Set [Optional Configuration](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dn763935.aspx) as needed, with these considerations:
trans-unit.target: Set [Optional Configuration](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dn763935.aspx) as needed, with these considerations:

trans-unit.source: a.
trans-unit.target: a.

trans-unit.source: Leave **Storage Account** as-is to create a new storage account with the VM name.
trans-unit.target: Leave **Storage Account** as-is to create a new storage account with the VM name.

trans-unit.source: b.
trans-unit.target: b.

trans-unit.source: Leave **Availability Set** as “Not Configured”.
trans-unit.target: Leave **Availability Set** as “Not Configured”.

trans-unit.source: c.
trans-unit.target: c.

trans-unit.source: Do not add any **endpoints** at this time.
trans-unit.target: Do not add any **endpoints** at this time.

trans-unit.source: Choose or create a resource group.
trans-unit.target: Choose or create a resource group.

trans-unit.source: Choose a **Subscription**.
trans-unit.target: Choose a **Subscription**.

trans-unit.source: Choose a **Location**.
trans-unit.target: Choose a **Location**.

trans-unit.source: Click **Create**, and the process of creating a VM will begin.
trans-unit.target: Click **Create**, and the process of creating a VM will begin.

trans-unit.source: After the VM has a status of **Running**, proceed to the next procedure.
trans-unit.target: After the VM has a status of **Running**, proceed to the next procedure.

trans-unit.source: To create your database using the Oracle Database VM in Azure
trans-unit.target: To create your database using the Oracle Database VM in Azure

trans-unit.source: Log in to the [Azure portal](https://ms.portal.azure.com/).
trans-unit.target: Log in to the [Azure portal](https://ms.portal.azure.com/).

trans-unit.source: Click **Virtual Machines**.
trans-unit.target: Click **Virtual Machines**.

trans-unit.source: Click the name of the VM that you want to log in to.
trans-unit.target: Click the name of the VM that you want to log in to.

trans-unit.source: Click **Connect**.
trans-unit.target: Click **Connect**.

trans-unit.source: Respond to the prompts as needed to connect to the VM.
trans-unit.target: Respond to the prompts as needed to connect to the VM.

trans-unit.source: When prompted for the administrator name and password, use the values that you provided when you created the VM.
trans-unit.target: When prompted for the administrator name and password, use the values that you provided when you created the VM.

trans-unit.source: Create an environment variable named **ORACLE_HOSTNAME** with its value set to the computer name of the VM.
trans-unit.target: Create an environment variable named **ORACLE_HOSTNAME** with its value set to the computer name of the VM.

trans-unit.source: You can create an environment variable using the following steps:
trans-unit.target: You can create an environment variable using the following steps:

trans-unit.source: a.
trans-unit.target: a.

trans-unit.source: In Windows, click **Start**, type **Control Panel**, click the **Control Panel** icon, click **System and Security**, click **System**, and then click **Advanced system settings**.
trans-unit.target: In Windows, click **Start**, type **Control Panel**, click the **Control Panel** icon, click **System and Security**, click **System**, and then click **Advanced system settings**.

trans-unit.source: b.
trans-unit.target: b.

trans-unit.source: Click the **Advanced** tab, and then click **Environment Variables**.
trans-unit.target: Click the **Advanced** tab, and then click **Environment Variables**.

trans-unit.source: c.
trans-unit.target: c.

trans-unit.source: Under the **System variables** section, click **New** to create the variable.
trans-unit.target: Under the **System variables** section, click **New** to create the variable.

trans-unit.source: d.
trans-unit.target: d.

trans-unit.source: In the **New system variable** dialog box, enter **ORACLE_HOSTNAME** for the name of the variable, and then enter the computer name of the VM as the value.
trans-unit.target: In the **New system variable** dialog box, enter **ORACLE_HOSTNAME** for the name of the variable, and then enter the computer name of the VM as the value.

trans-unit.source: To determine the computer name, open a command prompt and run **SET COMPUTERNAME** (the output of that command will contain the computer name).
trans-unit.target: To determine the computer name, open a command prompt and run **SET COMPUTERNAME** (the output of that command will contain the computer name).

trans-unit.source: e.
trans-unit.target: e.

trans-unit.source: Click **OK** to save the new environment variable and close the **New system variable** dialog box.
trans-unit.target: Click **OK** to save the new environment variable and close the **New system variable** dialog box.

trans-unit.source: f.
trans-unit.target: f.

trans-unit.source: Close the other dialog boxes that were opened by Control Panel.
trans-unit.target: Close the other dialog boxes that were opened by Control Panel.

trans-unit.source: In Windows, click **Start**, and then type **Database Configuration Assistant**.
trans-unit.target: In Windows, click **Start**, and then type **Database Configuration Assistant**.

trans-unit.source: Click the **Database Configuration Assistant** icon.
trans-unit.target: Click the **Database Configuration Assistant** icon.

trans-unit.source: Within the **Database Configuration Assistant** wizard, provide values as needed for each dialog box step:
trans-unit.target: Within the **Database Configuration Assistant** wizard, provide values as needed for each dialog box step:

trans-unit.source: a.
trans-unit.target: a.

trans-unit.source: **Step 1:** Click **Create Database** and then click **Next**.
trans-unit.target: **Step 1:** Click **Create Database** and then click **Next**.

trans-unit.source: b.
trans-unit.target: b.

trans-unit.source: **Step 2:** Enter a value for **Global Database Name**.
trans-unit.target: **Step 2:** Enter a value for **Global Database Name**.

trans-unit.source: Enter and confirm a value for **Administrative Password**.
trans-unit.target: Enter and confirm a value for **Administrative Password**.

trans-unit.source: This password is for your Oracle database **SYSTEM** user.
trans-unit.target: This password is for your Oracle database **SYSTEM** user.

trans-unit.source: Clear **Create As Container Database**.
trans-unit.target: Clear **Create As Container Database**.

trans-unit.source: Click **Next**.
trans-unit.target: Click **Next**.

trans-unit.source: c.
trans-unit.target: c.

trans-unit.source: **Step 3:** The prerequisites check should proceed automatically, advancing to **Step 4**.
trans-unit.target: **Step 3:** The prerequisites check should proceed automatically, advancing to **Step 4**.

trans-unit.source: d.
trans-unit.target: d.

trans-unit.source: **Step 4:** Review the **Create Database – Summary** options, and then click **Finish**.
trans-unit.target: **Step 4:** Review the **Create Database – Summary** options, and then click **Finish**.

trans-unit.source: e.
trans-unit.target: e.

trans-unit.source: **Step 5:** The **Progress Page** will report the status of your database creation.
trans-unit.target: **Step 5:** The **Progress Page** will report the status of your database creation.

trans-unit.source: f.
trans-unit.target: f.

trans-unit.source: After your database is created, you’ll have the option to use the **Password Management** dialog box.
trans-unit.target: After your database is created, you’ll have the option to use the **Password Management** dialog box.

trans-unit.source: Modify password settings if needed for your requirements, and then close the dialog boxes to exit the **Database Configuration Assistant** wizard.
trans-unit.target: Modify password settings if needed for your requirements, and then close the dialog boxes to exit the **Database Configuration Assistant** wizard.

trans-unit.source: To confirm your database is installed
trans-unit.target: To confirm your database is installed

trans-unit.source: Still logged in to your VM, start a SQL Plus command prompt.
trans-unit.target: Still logged in to your VM, start a SQL Plus command prompt.

trans-unit.source: In Windows, click *Start**, then type **SQL Plus**.
trans-unit.target: In Windows, click *Start**, then type **SQL Plus**.

trans-unit.source: Click the **SQL Plus** icon.
trans-unit.target: Click the **SQL Plus** icon.

trans-unit.source: When prompted, log in using the user name of **SYSTEM** and the password that you specified when you created the Oracle database.
trans-unit.target: When prompted, log in using the user name of **SYSTEM** and the password that you specified when you created the Oracle database.

trans-unit.source: Run the following command at the SQL Plus command prompt.
trans-unit.target: Run the following command at the SQL Plus command prompt.

trans-unit.source: The result should be the global name of the database that you created.
trans-unit.target: The result should be the global name of the database that you created.

trans-unit.source: Allowing your database to be reached remotely
trans-unit.target: Allowing your database to be reached remotely

trans-unit.source: To allow your database to be reached remotely (for example, from a client computer running Java code), you’ll need to start the database listener, open port 1521 in your virtual machine’s firewall, and create a public endpoint for port 1521.
trans-unit.target: To allow your database to be reached remotely (for example, from a client computer running Java code), you’ll need to start the database listener, open port 1521 in your virtual machine’s firewall, and create a public endpoint for port 1521.

trans-unit.source: Start the database listener
trans-unit.target: Start the database listener

trans-unit.source: Log in to your VM.
trans-unit.target: Log in to your VM.

trans-unit.source: Open a command prompt.
trans-unit.target: Open a command prompt.

trans-unit.source: At the command prompt, run the following command.
trans-unit.target: At the command prompt, run the following command.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] You can run **lsnrctl status** to check the status of the listener.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] You can run **lsnrctl status** to check the status of the listener.

trans-unit.source: When you want to stop the listener, you can run **lsnrctl stop**.
trans-unit.target: When you want to stop the listener, you can run **lsnrctl stop**.

trans-unit.source: Open port 1521 in your virtual machine’s firewall
trans-unit.target: Open port 1521 in your virtual machine’s firewall

trans-unit.source: While still logged in to your virtual machine, in Windows, click **Start**, type **Windows Firewall with Advanced Security**, and then click the **Windows Firewall with Advanced Security** icon.
trans-unit.target: While still logged in to your virtual machine, in Windows, click **Start**, type **Windows Firewall with Advanced Security**, and then click the **Windows Firewall with Advanced Security** icon.

trans-unit.source: This opens the **Windows Firewall with Advanced Security** management console.
trans-unit.target: This opens the **Windows Firewall with Advanced Security** management console.

trans-unit.source: Within the firewall management console, click **Inbound Rules** in the left pane (if you don’t see **Inbound Rules**, expand the top node in the left pane), and then click **New Rule** in the right pane.
trans-unit.target: Within the firewall management console, click **Inbound Rules** in the left pane (if you don’t see **Inbound Rules**, expand the top node in the left pane), and then click **New Rule** in the right pane.

trans-unit.source: For **Rule Type**, select **Port** and then click **Next**.
trans-unit.target: For **Rule Type**, select **Port** and then click **Next**.

trans-unit.source: For **Protocol and Port**, select **TCP**, select **Specific local ports**, enter **1521** for the port, and then click **Next**.
trans-unit.target: For **Protocol and Port**, select **TCP**, select **Specific local ports**, enter **1521** for the port, and then click **Next**.

trans-unit.source: Select **Allow the connection** and click **Next**.
trans-unit.target: Select **Allow the connection** and click **Next**.

trans-unit.source: Accept the defaults for the profiles for which the rule applies and then click **Next**.
trans-unit.target: Accept the defaults for the profiles for which the rule applies and then click **Next**.

trans-unit.source: Specify a name for the rule and optionally a description, and then click **Finish**.
trans-unit.target: Specify a name for the rule and optionally a description, and then click **Finish**.

trans-unit.source: Create a public endpoint for port 1521
trans-unit.target: Create a public endpoint for port 1521

trans-unit.source: Log in to the [Azure portal](https://ms.portal.azure.com/).
trans-unit.target: Log in to the [Azure portal](https://ms.portal.azure.com/).

trans-unit.source: Click **Browse**.
trans-unit.target: Click **Browse**.

trans-unit.source: Click **Virtual Machines**.
trans-unit.target: Click **Virtual Machines**.

trans-unit.source: Select the virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: Select the virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: Click **Settings**.
trans-unit.target: Click **Settings**.

trans-unit.source: Click **Endpoints**.
trans-unit.target: Click **Endpoints**.

trans-unit.source: Click **Add**.
trans-unit.target: Click **Add**.

trans-unit.source: Specify a name for the endpoint:
trans-unit.target: Specify a name for the endpoint:

trans-unit.source: a.
trans-unit.target: a.

trans-unit.source: Use **TCP** for the protocol.
trans-unit.target: Use **TCP** for the protocol.

trans-unit.source: b.
trans-unit.target: b.

trans-unit.source: Use **1521** for the public port.
trans-unit.target: Use **1521** for the public port.

trans-unit.source: c.
trans-unit.target: c.

trans-unit.source: Use **1521** for the private port.
trans-unit.target: Use **1521** for the private port.

trans-unit.source: Leave the rest of the options as-is.
trans-unit.target: Leave the rest of the options as-is.

trans-unit.source: Click **OK**.
trans-unit.target: Click **OK**.

trans-unit.source: Enabling Oracle Database Enterprise Manager remote access
trans-unit.target: Enabling Oracle Database Enterprise Manager remote access

trans-unit.source: If you want to enable remote access to Oracle Database Enterprise Manager, open port 5500 in your firewall, and create a virtual machine endpoint for 5500 in the Azure portal (using the steps shown earlier for opening port 1521 and creating an endpoint for 1521).
trans-unit.target: If you want to enable remote access to Oracle Database Enterprise Manager, open port 5500 in your firewall, and create a virtual machine endpoint for 5500 in the Azure portal (using the steps shown earlier for opening port 1521 and creating an endpoint for 1521).

trans-unit.source: Then, to run the Oracle Enterprise Manager from the remote computer, open a browser to the URL in the form of `http://<<unique_domain_name>>:5500/em`.
trans-unit.target: Then, to run the Oracle Enterprise Manager from the remote computer, open a browser to the URL in the form of `http://<<unique_domain_name>>:5500/em`.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] You can determine the value for *\<\<unique\_domain\_name\>\>* within the [Azure portal](https://ms.portal.azure.com/) by clicking **Virtual Machines** and then selecting the virtual machine that you are using to run Oracle Database).
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] You can determine the value for *\<\<unique\_domain\_name\>\>* within the [Azure portal](https://ms.portal.azure.com/) by clicking **Virtual Machines** and then selecting the virtual machine that you are using to run Oracle Database).

trans-unit.source: Configuring Popular Options and Advanced Options Bundles
trans-unit.target: Configuring Popular Options and Advanced Options Bundles

trans-unit.source: If you chose the **Oracle Database with Popular Options** or the **Oracle Database with Advanced Options bundle**, the next step is to configure the add-on features in your Oracle installation.
trans-unit.target: If you chose the **Oracle Database with Popular Options** or the **Oracle Database with Advanced Options bundle**, the next step is to configure the add-on features in your Oracle installation.

trans-unit.source: Refer to the Oracle documentation for instruction on setting these up on Windows, as configurations can vary widely based on your needs of each individual component.
trans-unit.target: Refer to the Oracle documentation for instruction on setting these up on Windows, as configurations can vary widely based on your needs of each individual component.

trans-unit.source: The **Oracle Database with Popular Options bundle** includes Oracle Database Enterprise Edition and license-included instances of [Partitioning](http://www.oracle.com/us/products/database/options/partitioning/overview/index.html), [Active Data Guard](http://www.oracle.com/us/products/database/options/active-data-guard/overview/index.html), [Oracle Tuning Pack for Database](http://docs.oracle.com/html/A86647_01/tun_ovw.htm), [Oracle Diagnostics Pack for Database](http://docs.oracle.com/cd/B28359_01/license.111/b28287/options.htm#CIHIHDDJ), and [Oracle Lifecycle Management Pack for Database](http://www.oracle.com/technetwork/oem/lifecycle-mgmt-495331.html).
trans-unit.target: The **Oracle Database with Popular Options bundle** includes Oracle Database Enterprise Edition and license-included instances of [Partitioning](http://www.oracle.com/us/products/database/options/partitioning/overview/index.html), [Active Data Guard](http://www.oracle.com/us/products/database/options/active-data-guard/overview/index.html), [Oracle Tuning Pack for Database](http://docs.oracle.com/html/A86647_01/tun_ovw.htm), [Oracle Diagnostics Pack for Database](http://docs.oracle.com/cd/B28359_01/license.111/b28287/options.htm#CIHIHDDJ), and [Oracle Lifecycle Management Pack for Database](http://www.oracle.com/technetwork/oem/lifecycle-mgmt-495331.html).

trans-unit.source: The **Oracle Database with Advanced Options bundle** includes license-included instances of all the options in the Popular Options bundle, plus [Advanced Compression](http://www.oracle.com/us/products/database/options/advanced-compression/overview/index.html), [Advanced Security](http://www.oracle.com/us/products/database/options/advanced-security/overview/index.html), [Label Security](http://www.oracle.com/us/products/database/options/label-security/overview/index.html), [Database Vault](http://www.oracle.com/us/products/database/options/database-vault/overview/index.html), [Advanced Analytics](http://www.oracle.com/us/products/database/options/advanced-analytics/overview/index.html), [OLAP](http://docs.oracle.com/cd/E11882_01/license.112/e47877/options.htm#CIHGDEEF), [Spatial and Graph](http://docs.oracle.com/cd/E11882_01/license.112/e47877/options.htm#CIHGDEEF), [In-Memory Database Cache](http://www.oracle.com/technetwork/products/timesten/overview/timesten-imdb-cache-101293.html), [Data Masking Pack](http://docs.oracle.com/cd/E11882_01/license.112/e47877/options.htm#CHDGEEBB), and the Oracle Test Data Management Pack (as part of the Data Masking Pack).
trans-unit.target: The **Oracle Database with Advanced Options bundle** includes license-included instances of all the options in the Popular Options bundle, plus [Advanced Compression](http://www.oracle.com/us/products/database/options/advanced-compression/overview/index.html), [Advanced Security](http://www.oracle.com/us/products/database/options/advanced-security/overview/index.html), [Label Security](http://www.oracle.com/us/products/database/options/label-security/overview/index.html), [Database Vault](http://www.oracle.com/us/products/database/options/database-vault/overview/index.html), [Advanced Analytics](http://www.oracle.com/us/products/database/options/advanced-analytics/overview/index.html), [OLAP](http://docs.oracle.com/cd/E11882_01/license.112/e47877/options.htm#CIHGDEEF), [Spatial and Graph](http://docs.oracle.com/cd/E11882_01/license.112/e47877/options.htm#CIHGDEEF), [In-Memory Database Cache](http://www.oracle.com/technetwork/products/timesten/overview/timesten-imdb-cache-101293.html), [Data Masking Pack](http://docs.oracle.com/cd/E11882_01/license.112/e47877/options.htm#CHDGEEBB), and the Oracle Test Data Management Pack (as part of the Data Masking Pack).

trans-unit.source: Additional resources
trans-unit.target: Additional resources

trans-unit.source: Now that you’ve set up your virtual machine and created your database, see the following topics for additional information.
trans-unit.target: Now that you’ve set up your virtual machine and created your database, see the following topics for additional information.
